An account of the reforms is given in Creedy and Disney (1988).

A SERPS pension is calculated as a fraction of the individual's total 'qualifying earnings', where qualifying earnings are post-1978 earnings between the NI floor and ceiling. The indexation of the N1 floor and ceiling to prices (rather than earnings) will have the effect of raising qualifying earnings until average earnings reach the N1 ceiling, and thereafter will begin to reduce qualifying earnings, eventually below what they would have with earnings indexation. SERPS entitlements, and corresponding expenditures, will consequently be higher for a period, but will eventually be reduced.
